developers out there is basically an f-sharp representation of kind of the elm model
so if you're doing any ui programming in the web today you may be using patterns like mvc
and if you're doing wpf or silverlight in the years gone by you may know things like mvvm
so the elm pattern um again we'll talk about that in a bit um is basically called the mvu pattern
so it stands for model update uh and we'll talk about that as well um the idea really for safe was to say
if you want to write web applications in fsharp rather than you may be having to use
libraries that weren't designed to take full advantage of fsharp where you maybe have to write code in a way that feels
somehow unnatural we wanted to turn it on its head and say why not write libraries and frameworks
that let f sharp developers write how they want to but still take advantage of all
of the really great platforms that are out there so it's kind of a win-win situation that's that's really what
we're targeting the same stack so why would you want to use it um now i

you can write all of that but yet you can still target javascript you can share types between client and
server so that means if ever you've written a web application

context um so the mvu pattern is this ui pattern um like mvc or mv vm as i said
and the important thing about it is it's a really good fit for functional programming where you have things like
immutable data and expressions everywhere and i think even blazer is potentially
getting something similar to mvu or they're calling it mvu it's kind of nvus what really happens is you have a model
which is just at its most basic a class or set of classes and types
so if you had i don't know order processing management system or maybe something like amazon you may have
a type that's got things on it like the basket and what items are going to be shown on the screen and what's the
search results and who's the user that's logged in and this type gets passed into a function
which is called either the view function or the render function whatever and that functions job is simply i've been given
this current state please render it to the screen that's its only job it's got one job
it doesn't care about um state changes or anything like that it's only job is i've been given this model
give me a view what happens afterwards is then there are ui events that come through button clicks
piped into text box and so on and so forth and those are then sent into a function called update
and each of those will be different messages so that could be item added to cart card cleared
checkout complete and the job of the update function is basically to say given this message
and the previous model the previous state give me a new state so it might be
previously we had an empty cart message is add item to cart the new
model is the old model with this extra item added into the cart that's it
and that whole flow just continues forever there's no mutable state here there's no
kind of model where we're changing things in the middle the only place you change the only place you do anything is
in this one function called update um which gives you back a copy a new copy of a model and there's a lot of
really nice benefits to this one is that it simplifies the way that we think about our state changes
you don't have to think about sort of uni bi-directional flows everything just goes one way you get data in you write a
function that gives you some data out that's pretty much it and i'll show you that in a minute with
